title: 108_hr4431
content: The Act may be cited as "One Church, One Child Act of 2004". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that many States are experiencing shortages of qualified foster and adoptive parents. A 2002 report highlighted a 68% increase in children in foster care from 1984 to 1995, while the number of foster parents decreased by 4%. Additionally, in 2001, only 50,000 children were adopted from foster care, leaving 126,000 children awaiting adoption. Since 2001, 50,000 children were adopted from foster care, with 126,000 still awaiting adoption after an average of 44 months in foster care. The increase in adoptions since 1997 has led to a greater need for post-adoption services and skilled providers. One Church, One Child is a national faith-based organization. One Church, One Child is a national foster care and adoption ministry founded in Chicago in 1980 by Father George Clements. Their mission is to provide services for at-risk children and support adoptive, foster, and kinship families, having successfully placed over 140,000 children in adoptive families nationwide. One Church, One Child programs have placed over 140,000 children in adoptive families nationwide. Despite their success, these programs have received limited federal funding. A federally-funded grant program to support similar recruitment and support services for foster and adoptive parents modeled on this concept would be beneficial. Recruitment of foster and adoptive parents based on the One Church, One Child concept will increase the pool of qualified parents for abused and neglected children. SEC. 479B. ONE CHURCH, ONE CHILD GRANTS. This section adds grants under the One Church, One Child concept to increase qualified parents for abused and neglected children. The Secretary will provide competitive grants to eligible entities to establish or expand programs that recruit and train foster and adoptive parents through public, private, and faith-based organizations. Support services will also be provided to adoptive and foster children and their families. The eligible entities, including government agencies, nonprofit organizations, and private entities, can apply for grants to recruit and train foster and adoptive parents. Support services will be provided to adoptive and foster children and their families. The eligible entities can apply for grants to recruit and train foster and adoptive parents. The application must include a project description detailing the programs and services to be provided to children and prospective adoptive and foster parents. The eligible entities can apply for grants to recruit and train foster and adoptive parents, including post-placement supportive services. The entity must describe how they will coordinate with State and local entities and the national clearinghouse, and provide records, reports, and audits. The eligible entities applying for grants must coordinate with State and local entities and the national clearinghouse. They are required to maintain records, submit reports, and cooperate with audits as necessary for oversight. The term 'State' includes all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate up to $20,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2005 through 2009 to carry out grants for eligible entities in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. Grant funds must be expended within three years. The Secretary can redistribute any unexpended grant funds to eligible entities in need. Grants must be expended within three years, and any unused funds must be remitted to the Secretary. Religious organizations will not face discrimination in grant awards. Religious organizations will be considered equally for grants under this section, as long as the grant is implemented in line with the Establishment Clause. State or local governments cannot discriminate against religious organizations seeking to participate in programs funded under this section. Religious organizations can participate in programs funded under this section without being required to alter their internal governance or remove religious symbols from their premises. Religious organizations receiving funds under this section must not use the funds for sectarian worship, instruction, or proselytization. They are also required to adhere to fiscal accountability regulations similar to other nongovernmental organizations. Religious organizations receiving funds under this section must adhere to fiscal accountability regulations, including keeping the funds separate from other organization funds. SEC. 479C. National Clearinghouse for Adoption Promotion and Foster Parent Recruitment Programs; Annual Report to Congress. The Secretary will contract with a nonprofit organization to assist in adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment programs at the national level. The nonprofit organization will assist in coordinating activities for recruitment of foster and adoptive parents, providing post-placement support, and offering technical assistance and training for grantees. The nonprofit organization will provide assistance and training for grantees, identify and disseminate best practices for recruiting and training prospective foster and adoptive parents, and collect information on the effectiveness of funded programs. The nonprofit organization will provide assistance and training for grantees to recruit foster and adoptive parents, collect data for program evaluation, and assist the Secretary in preparing required reports. The nationally recognized nonprofit organization selected by the Secretary provides consultation, training, and support for faith-based and community organizations interested in adoption promotion and foster parent recruitment. The selected nonprofit organization has a national reputation for working with faith-based and community organizations to recruit and train foster and adoptive parents, with extensive experience in programs based on the One Church, One Child model. The One Church, One Child model receives funding of up to $1,000,000 annually from 2005 to 2009. The Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress detailing the number of entities receiving grants and foster parents involved. The Secretary must provide annual reports to Congress on the One Church, One Child model, including the number of entities receiving grants, foster parents recruited, children placed, and placement outcomes. Additional relevant information may also be included as determined by the Secretary.
